burns.What temperature should the water be to: The water should be cool, but not cold, ideally around room temperature to help soothe the burn without causing further tissue damage.
burns.Why should I avoid using cold water?: Cold water can cause further damage to the burned tissue by constricting blood flow and potentially worsening the injury.
burns.What is a sterile, non-adhesive bandage?: A sterile, non-adhesive bandage is a clean, germ-free bandage that doesn't stick to the wound, reducing the risk of infection and further injury when removed.
burns.Can I use any clean cloth to cover the b: Yes, if a sterile bandage is not available, you can use a clean cloth as a temporary measure to protect the burn.
burns.What are over-the-counter pain relievers: Over-the-counter pain relievers are medications available without a prescription, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, that help reduce pain and inflammation.
burns.How do ibuprofen and acetaminophen help: Ibuprofen and acetaminophen help reduce inflammation and pain, providing relief from the discomfort caused by burns.
burns.Why shouldn't I apply ice directly to th: Applying ice directly to a burn can cause frostbite and further tissue damage by reducing blood flow to the area.
burns.What can happen if I use ice on a burn?: Using ice on a burn can cause additional injury by freezing the skin and tissue, leading to more damage and slower healing.

cuts_and_scrapes.How long should I rinse the wound under: You should rinse the wound under running water for at least 5 minutes to remove debris and reduce the risk of infection.
cuts_and_scrapes.What is an antiseptic solution?: An antiseptic solution is a liquid or cream that prevents infection by killing or slowing the growth of microorganisms. Examples include hydrogen peroxide and alcohol.
cuts_and_scrapes.How do I apply an antiseptic solution pr: To apply an antiseptic solution, clean your hands, then gently apply the solution to the wound using a clean cotton pad or swab.
cuts_and_scrapes.What is a sterile bandage?: A sterile bandage is a clean, germ-free bandage that is used to protect wounds from infection and further injury.
cuts_and_scrapes.Can I use any type of bandage to cover t: It's best to use a sterile bandage to minimize the risk of infection. If a sterile bandage is not available, ensure the bandage you use is clean.

cuts_and_scrapes.What should I do if the bleeding doesn't: If the bleeding doesn't stop after applying pressure for several minutes, seek medical attention immediately.

cuts_and_scrapes.What are signs of infection in a cut or: Signs of infection in a cut or scrape include increased pain, redness, swelling, pus, and warmth around the affected area.

choking.How can I tell if someone is choking?: You can tell someone is choking if they are unable to speak, breathe, or cough forcefully. They might also clutch their throat or appear panicked.
choking.What should I do if they can speak or co: If the person can speak or cough, encourage them to continue coughing to try to dislodge the object themselves.
choking.Why is coughing important when someone i: Coughing is the body's natural way to expel an object from the airway. It can help dislodge the obstruction without the need for further intervention.
choking.How long should I encourage them to coug: Encourage them to cough as long as they can still breathe and the coughing is forceful. If they become unable to cough, you may need to perform the Heimlich maneuver.
choking.What is the Heimlich maneuver?: The Heimlich maneuver is a first aid procedure used to treat upper airway obstructions (choking) by dislodging the object with abdominal thrusts.
choking.How do I properly perform the Heimlich m: To perform the Heimlich maneuver, stand behind the person, wrap your arms around their waist, make a fist with one hand, place it above their navel, grasp your fist with your other hand, and thrust inward and upward.
choking.What should I do if the person is too la: If the person is too large or pregnant, perform chest thrusts instead of abdominal thrusts. Position your hands in the center of the chest and push hard and fast.
choking.What should I do if the person is a chil: For a child, use less force when performing the Heimlich maneuver. For an infant, use a combination of back blows and chest thrusts to dislodge the object.
choking.When should I call emergency services fo: Call emergency services immediately if the person cannot breathe, cough, or speak, and the Heimlich maneuver is not successful in dislodging the object.
choking.What information should I provide when c: When calling for emergency help, provide your location, describe the situation, and inform them that someone is choking and in need of immediate assistance.

cardiac_arrest.What information should I provide when c: When calling emergency services, provide your location, describe the situation, mention that the person is in cardiac arrest, and follow any instructions given by the dispatcher.
cardiac_arrest.Should I stay on the line with the dispa: Yes, stay on the line with the dispatcher until they tell you it is okay to hang up. They can provide instructions and support while help is on the way.
cardiac_arrest.How do I check for responsiveness?: To check for responsiveness, tap the person on the shoulder and shout their name or ask loudly if they are okay. Look for any movement or response.
cardiac_arrest.What should I do if the person is respon: If the person is responsive but not breathing properly, call emergency services and monitor their condition. Be prepared to start CPR if their condition worsens.
cardiac_arrest.What is CPR?: CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) is an emergency procedure that involves chest compressions and sometimes rescue breaths to maintain circulation and breathing in a person whose heart has stopped.
cardiac_arrest.How do I perform CPR correctly?: To perform CPR, place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest, place your other hand on top, and press down hard and fast, at least 2 inches deep and at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.
cardiac_arrest.How do I know if I’m pressing deep enoug: You should press down at least 2 inches deep and aim for a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute. Counting out loud can help you maintain the correct pace.
cardiac_arrest.Should I perform rescue breaths along wi: If you are trained in CPR, provide rescue breaths after every 30 compressions. If not, continue with chest compressions until help arrives.
cardiac_arrest.What is an AED?: An AED (Automated External Defibrillator) is a portable device that checks the heart rhythm and can send an electric shock to the heart to try to restore a normal rhythm.
cardiac_arrest.How do I use an AED properly?: To use an AED, turn it on and follow the voice prompts. Attach the pads to the person's bare chest as shown in the diagrams on the pads and stand clear while the AED analyzes the heart rhythm and delivers a shock if needed.
cardiac_arrest.What if I don't know how to use an AED?: Most AEDs provide clear voice instructions that guide you through each step. If one is available, use it even if you are unsure, as it can significantly increase the person's chance of survival.
cardiac_arrest.How long should I continue performing CP: Continue performing CPR until emergency responders arrive, the person shows signs of life (like breathing), or you are physically unable to continue.
cardiac_arrest.What should I do if the person starts br: If the person starts breathing again, place them in the recovery position (on their side) and continue to monitor their breathing and condition until help arrives.

Steps to Perform CPR
Check Responsiveness: Gently shake the person and shout to see if they respond.
Call for Help: If there is no response, call emergency services immediately.
Open the Airway: Tilt the person's head back slightly to open the airway.
Check for Breathing: Look, listen, and feel for breathing for no more than 10 seconds.
Chest Compressions:
Place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest, place the other hand on top, and interlock your fingers.
Keep your elbows straight and use your body weight to compress the chest at least 2 inches deep at a rate of 100 to 120 compressions per minute.
Rescue Breaths (if trained and able):
After 30 compressions, give 2 rescue breaths.
Pinch the person's nose, cover their mouth with yours, and blow until you see the chest rise.
Important Points
Continue CPR: Continue cycles of 30 chest compressions and 2 rescue breaths until medical help arrives or the person shows signs of life.
Hands-Only CPR: If you are not trained in rescue breaths or uncomfortable performing them, you can do hands-only CPR, which involves continuous chest compressions without rescue breaths.
